Planned changes to improve safety;

GlobalFoundries is committed to continuous improvement as it relates to health, safety, and the environment. The Malta team will continue to look for, develop, and periodically review programs to ensure that process safety is evolving based on industry best practices. Additionally, GlobalFoundries will review any code / regulatory updates and changes in accordance with RMP requirements to ensure the covered process units are meeting the safety requirements published by recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.

The five-year accident history;

The Risk Management Plan rule identified any accident as “all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.” (§68.42(a))

GlobalFoundries has implemented an incident investigation program for all incidents that occur at the site, including chemical releases from process units. The Malta facility has had no releases of anhydrous ammonia or ammonium hydroxide that would trigger an RMP-related incident as required under (§68.42(a)).

The emergency response program;

The Malta facility has a trained and well-equipped Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) team to respond to various foreseeable incidents that could occur at the campus. The team has been trained for responding to spills / releases of hazardous materials, medical response, confined space entry, and high angle rescue. In addition to these, the team also has fire brigade members who are trained in interior structural firefighting. The team is led by full-time dedicated resources for management of the HAZWOPER team and fire brigade at Fab 8. 

The site has various emergency response procedures for various emergency situations / scenarios under 29 CFR 1910.120. Additionally, the site has established a written policy for the management of the fire brigade as required under 29 CFR 1910.156. These programs are periodically reviewed by the program owner and updated as needed based on changes. The facility also uses the NIMS Incident Command system for emergency response management.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps;

GlobalFoundries has extensive experience in managing highly hazardous chemicals as part of the semi-conductor manufacturing process. For all chemical processes (including Program Level 1 RMP systems) the site has implemented several risk management programs including, but not limited to, Hazard Communication, Emergency Planning / Response, Personal Protective Equipment, as well as inspection, testing, and preventative maintenance programs. These systems are also designed in accordance with industry best practices for engineering controls such as gas detection and exhausted enclosures. 

For the Anhydrous Ammonia system (Program Level 3) the site has implemented the 14 elements required by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration’s Process Safety Management Rule as well as the Environmental Protection Agency’s Risk Management Plan Rule. These elements include:
1.	Employee Participation
2.	Process Safety Information
3.	Process Hazard Analysis
4.	Operating Procedures
5.	Training
6.	Management of Change
7.	Pre-Startup Safety Review
8.	Hot Work
9.	Mechanical Integrity
10.	Contractor Management
11.	Emergency Planning / Response
12.	Incident Investigation
13.	Compliance Audits
14.	Trade Secrets
